# Motivation

- *Proof-Based Math Readings* is a free and independent online reading group where we study mathematics required in economics master's/PhD programs using an intuitive approach.
- This session of the reading group is on *Large Sample Theory*.

# Prerequisites

- CGPA: 3.00/4.00.
- Proof and Real Analysis books/playlists listed below.
- Please use the [\faLink Application Form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf3OxwYuAwiDXMVTCQ_x3FTtKnHmRRkl_SXlpdfqTDty06PxQ/viewform) to join our reading group anytime.
- Applicants are informed about their application results within a week via email.

# Format

- This session takes 12 weeks.
- We discuss the topics/exercises that we struggle with at [\faDiscord Proof-Based Math Readings \[Discord\]](https://discord.com).
- We do not have face-to-face/online meetings due to the size of the group.
- Members are expected to read the chapters, and watch the chapter videos from the book's playlist.

# Resources

## Main Book and Main Book's Playlist

**Elements of Large-Sample Theory** is our main book for this session because it is well-written and well-structured.  
Jingyi Jessica Li's playlist is our main playlist because her narrative is just great.

\begin{itemize}
  \item[\faBook] Elements of Large-Sample Theory - E. L. Lehmann (1999) $\mspace{107mu} \rightarrow$ Easier to read

  \item[\faBook] \href{https://www.math.ucla.edu/~tom/LST/Errata.pdf}{A Course in Large Sample Theory - Thomas S. Ferguson (2002, Errata)}
  \item[\faYoutube] \href{https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAYxx7zX5F1NKukTVwMADi1D5dbufWJkz}{Large Sample Theory - Jingyi Jessica Li (Playlist, 2021)}

\end{itemize}

# Reading Schedule

- **ELST** is the abbreviation of **Elements of Large-Sample Theory - E. L. Lehmann (1999)**.

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## **\faBook ELST, Chapter 1: Mathematical Background \hfill Week 01-02 \faCalendar* **

\begin{itemize}
  \item[] The concept of limit
  \item[] Embedding sequences
  \item[] Infinite series
  \item[] Order relations and rates of convergence
  \item[] Continuity
  \item[] Distributions
\end{itemize}
:::

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## **\faBook ELST, Chapter 2: Convergence in Probability and in Law \hfill Week 03-04-05-06 \faCalendar* **

\begin{itemize}
  \item[] Convergence in probability
  \item[] Applications
  \item[] Convergence in law
  \item[] The central limit theorem
  \item[] Taylor's theorem and the delta method
  \item[] Uniform convergence
  \item[] The CLT for independent non-identical random variables
  \item[] Central limit theorem for dependent variables
\end{itemize}
:::

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## **\faBook ELST, Chapter 3: Performance of Statistical Tests \hfill Week 07-08-09 \faCalendar* **

\begin{itemize}
  \item[] Critical values
  \item[] Comparing two treatments
  \item[] Power and sample size
  \item[] Comparison of tests: Relative efficiency
  \item[] Robustness
\end{itemize}
:::

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## **\faBook ELST, Chapter 4: Estimation \hfill Week 10-11-12 \faCalendar* **

\begin{itemize}
  \item[] Confidence intervals
  \item[] Accuracy of point estimators
  \item[] Comparing estimators
  \item[] Sampling from a finite population
\end{itemize}
:::
